title: Bankruptcy chapter 7. Can I get rid of a SBA loan in chap 7? Relentless bank has already attacked my 401(k). Can they do that?
question: They are garnishing/levying my 401(k). Can they do that and what can I do to get that money back? Will a chapter 7 take care of this debt? Please help. I am in California if that matters.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Automatic stays in bankruptcy,Bankruptcy adversary proceeding,Bankruptcy documents,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Retirement benefits and ERISA
answers:
Retirement accounts, 401(K) accounts, and similar savings accounts are usually exempt 100% in California under C.C.P. § 703.140(b)(10)(E). They have to be ERISA qualified - and most usually are.

The problem is whether you granted any security interest in the retirement account as part of the SBA loan agreement. That’s pretty unusual, and I have not seen that before.

However, if they try to enforce this, your BK attorney can object to the claim on the basis that it impairs your exemptions.

And you should get the BK process started as soon as possible. Once the BK case is on file, the automatic stay will halt any further garnishing/levying of the 401(k), and any money seized within 90 days prior to the date the BK case is filed can be recovered as a preference.

I must stress that you MUST get a highly experienced attorney to handle this one. The SBA is sure to try to fight this if such a security agreement is in the loan documents.

There is an old saying among bankruptcy lawyers that the "SBA will take your first born child" as collateral for any loan they provide. Read your loan paperwork, but my guess is you signed over the title to the 401K account when you got the loan and that the SBA is simply attaching (not attacking) property you put up for collateral. Bankruptcy does not change lien rights except in extraordinary circumstances. Hope this perspective helps!

I agree with Mr. Shields. However, any creditor has the option of filing an adversary proceeding requesting that its debt is nondischargeable on grounds which include but are not limited to misrepresentation in the obtaining of the debt, willful and malicious actions on part of the debtor. It is unlikely that the SBA would pursue such an action.

Yes. SBA loans are dischargeable in C7 BK. However, if you personally guaranteed the loan you may be personally liable. Personal liability is also dischargeable in BK.
No. Creditor cannot execute against 401(k) and other ERISA qualified assets. Most 401(k) plans are ERISA qualified. However, you must take action to protect the 401(k) from execution by creditor.
Consult BK counsel to ensure C7 BK will accomplish your goals and is best solution for you..
